text: [Music]
hi everyone bike then he chain tano here
the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for
a review of the new dear hoof album
actually you can this is the 18th studio
lp from indie rock vets dear hoof one of
the most consistent and idiosyncratic
bands on the planet with just unwavering
style musicianship and output it's
frankly kind of easy to take a band like
deirjo for granted assuming they're
always going to be there providing the
light and creativity they do like the
sun rising every morning cause after all
these years the band is still sounding
like a well-oiled machine greg's
drumming is still effortlessly groovy
nuanced flashy and virtuous john and
ed's guitar work is still melodic
technical expressive and mind-bending
and how many times now has satomi proven
herself to be a one-of-a-kind singer and
lyricist not to mention the band has
collectively been going into a lot of
their latest projects with either
topical or aesthetic concepts in mind to
kind of tie everything together their
last one future teenage cave artists was
a fitting lp for 2020 as it was one of
the band's noisiest and most rudimentary
and dystopian record so far but actually
you can by comparison seems relatively
free of the
heady dystopian and kind of chaotic
rigmarole the tracks here aren't too
abrasive or psychedelic and the mixes on
these tracks are some of the clearest
and punchiest deerhoof have offered in a
while too the whole thing runs at a
brisk nine tracks in 32 minutes i guess
what i'm trying to say here is that dear
hoof is in banger mode on this record
with some of their brightest guitar
lines and melodies ever hardest drum
beats too i'm feeling a renewed sense of
hope on this lp as well some of the
attitudes and feelings on these songs
remind me of one of the band's more
under-appreciated rebellion anthems i
will spite survive off of their mountain
moves project i feel like that same
energy and philosophy is returning on
this record with a vengeance as there
are numerous tracks here where it sounds
like the band is finding the will to
fight on and find beauty in the world
around them some of the wild baroque and
latin influences flowing throughout
these tracks are refreshing too the
classical melody and harmony breaks on
beyond barred ou gates of hell are
fantastic and guitarist ed rodriguez has
been quoted talking about the mexican
music influences that went into his
guitar lines on scarcity is manufactured
that ring through beautifully i think
satomi's especially in her bag on this
one hook wise as well crime is a slow
motion love song
is uh easily one of her sweetest
choruses ever on ancient mysteries
described the way it hits as well
between these chaotic guitar passages
makes it such a euphoric release i also
love her later descriptions of criminal
enterprises later on the song old gangs
being cash only mid gangs being card
only in new gangs being hearts only then
our philosophy is fiction i'm enamored
with lyrically the way that it describes
a very artificial future with artificial
crying and praying as well as simulated
dancing seems like a dystopian
description of a replacement for our
increasingly
numb and uh i guess isolated world plus
satomi's vocal melody here is absolutely
heart-wrenching and haunting and the
lyrical creativity continues on to the
song department of corrections which
uses a jail setting as a clever metaphor
of sorts plus satomi's playful
descriptions of fishing on epic love
poem saying that a big one is coming
combine that with some of the rockin and
fun rips on the track and greg's mathy
drumming and improvisations across
different progressions on the song like
this is classic deerhoof all the way the
bridge of this track is also one of the
trippiest moments on the lp as satomi is
singing about being underwater meanwhile
the guitars are getting more and more
atmospheric and drenched with effects so
the finer details on this record are
nice even if they don't necessarily you
know come through with too much a
subtlety because everything on the
record is so goddamn loud but really the
biggest selling point of this lp is just
how exhilarating and energized the songs
and performances are dear hoof on this
lp may bring the experience of aging gen
xers but uh
they're playing here they're performing
here like a bunch of [ __ ] teenagers
like the booming drums and tight
harmonized guitar licks on department of
corrections uh hit like i'm being beaten
to death by an octopus with boxing
gloves on the crushing hits of bass and
noise on scarcity is manufactured is
like a musical avalanche and the
drumming on plant thief is incredible
greg has absolutely gregan and nobody
for that matter has no business
drumming this wildly past the age of 50.
plus the instrumental passages in the
second half of divine comedy makes for
one of the most triumphant finishes of
any deer hoof album so overall i saw
this as a very great effort from
deerhoof nothing super conceptual or
over the top for them there are points
like maybe the first leg of divine
comedy that serve as a reminder that
maybe there weren't that many low key
moments or ballads in the track list
maybe as many as there should have been
the baroque and latin influences that
were certainly pushed forward in the
promotion of this album i think could
have uh influenced a bit more of the
record but still this is a fun and tight
set of bops from one of the most unique
indie and noise rock bands out there and
i'm feeling a strong seven to a light
eight on it uh tran position have you
given this album a listen did you love
it did you hate it what would you rate
it you're the best you're the best what
should i review next hit the like if you
like please subscribe and please don't
cry hit that up or uh no i hit what up
there's a video next to my head hit that
up or the link to subscribe to the
channel
anthony fantano dear huff forever
